unnormalised: Okay, so, my little one, Arjun, spiked a fever last week. 102°F! Freaked me right out. As a first-time mom, everything feels like a CODE RED situation, you know? Rushed him straight to Dr. Mehra at Rainbow Children's Hospital. Heard she's the best pediatrician in Bangalore.
normalised: Okay, so, my little one, Arjun, spiked a fever last week. one hundred and two degree fahrenheit! Freaked me right out. As a first-time mom, everything feels like a C-O-D-E R-E-D situation, you know? Rushed him straight to Doctor Mehra at Rainbow Children's Hospital. Heard she's the best pediatrician in Bangalore.

unnormalised: Apparently, viral fevers are super common in kiddos, especially during monsoon season. Dr. Mehra said, "Don't panic! It's probably just a routine thing." Easy for her to say! She examined Arjun thoroughly, checked his throat, his ears - the whole shebang. Asked about his vaccination schedule too. Reminded me he’s due for his MMR vaccine on 15/10/2024. Gotta prep for that crying session, sigh.
normalised: Apparently, viral fevers are super common in kiddos, especially during monsoon season. Doctor Mehra said, "Don't panic! It's probably just a routine thing." Easy for her to say! She examined Arjun thoroughly, checked his throat, his ears - the whole shebang. Asked about his vaccination schedule too. Reminded me he’s due for his M-M-R vaccine on fifteenth october two thousand and twenty four. Gotta prep for that crying session, sigh.

unnormalised: She prescribed Calpol 250mg syrup every 6 hrs if the fever crossed 100°F. And lots of fluids! Coconut water, dal paani, you name it. Basically, anything to keep him hydrated. She also mentioned something about looking out for other symptoms like rash or breathing difficulty, just in case it was more than just a regular fever. No rash, thank God.
normalised: She prescribed Calpol two hundred and fifty milligram syrup every six hours if the fever crossed one hundred degree fahrenheit. And lots of fluids! Coconut water, dal paani, you name it. Basically, anything to keep him hydrated. She also mentioned something about looking out for other symptoms like rash or breathing difficulty, just in case it was more than just a regular fever. No rash, thank God.

unnormalised: The worst part? Arjun wouldn't eat anything! Refused his usual dal chawal. Only wanted to be cuddled. Mommy duties at their finest, eh? Spent the next 2 days just glued to his side, monitoring his temp. Every 2 hrs, diligently noted down, as if I am a medical professional. It was a tad obsessive.
normalised: The worst part? Arjun wouldn't eat anything! Refused his usual dal chawal. Only wanted to be cuddled. Mommy duties at their finest, eh? Spent the next two days just glued to his side, monitoring his temperature. Every two hours, diligently noted down, as if I am a medical professional. It was a tad obsessive.

unnormalised: On day 3, the fever finally started to subside. Relief! He even managed a few bites of his favorite khichdi. Victory! Dr. Mehra had also asked to get a CBC done just to rule out any bacterial infections, so that report was normal too. All good.
normalised: On day three, the fever finally started to subside. Relief! He even managed a few bites of his favorite khichdi. Victory! Doctor Mehra had also asked to get a C-B-C done just to rule out any bacterial infections, so that report was normal too. All good.

unnormalised: It made me think, though, how quickly these little ones catch stuff. All those playdates and visits to the park probably expose them to all sorts of germs. Gotta be more vigilant about washing hands and keeping things clean. Maybe invest in a good sanitizer?
normalised: It made me think, though, how quickly these little ones catch stuff. All those playdates and visits to the park probably expose them to all sorts of germs. Gotta be more vigilant about washing hands and keeping things clean. Maybe invest in a good sanitizer?

unnormalised: So, my advice to other new parents: don't freak out (easier said than done, I know!). Trust your instincts, monitor your child closely, and find a pediatrician you trust, like Dr. Mehra. And always, ALWAYS, have Calpol handy! It's been a lifesaver.
normalised: So, my advice to other new parents: don't freak out (easier said than done, I know!). Trust your instincts, monitor your child closely, and find a pediatrician you trust, like Doctor Mehra. And always, A-L-W-A-Y-S, have Calpol handy! It's been a lifesaver.

unnormalised: And remember, this too shall pass. They will be back to climbing on furniture and creating chaos in no time, trust me. Just cherish those cuddle moments while you can! Now, off to book Arjun's vaccination appointment, wish me luck!
